sn47.39:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.39:1.3.eng: And what is the development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

sn47.39:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.39:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.39:1.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.39:1.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.39:1.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.39:1.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanā”ti.
sn47.39:1.8.eng: This is the development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati sālāya brāhmaṇagāme.
sn47.4:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans near the brahmin village of Sālā.

sn47.4:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi …pe… etadavoca:
sn47.4:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn47.4:2.1.pli: “Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, te vo, bhikkhave, bhikkhū catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanāya samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
sn47.4:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, those mendicants who are junior—recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.4:2.3.pli: Etha tumhe, āvuso, kāye kāyānupassino viharatha ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, kāyassa yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya;
sn47.4:2.3.eng: Please, reverends, meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to truly know the body.

sn47.4:2.4.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharatha ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, vedanānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya;
sn47.4:2.4.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to truly know feelings.

sn47.4:2.5.pli: citte cittānupassino viharatha ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, cittassa yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya;
sn47.4:2.5.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to truly know the mind.

sn47.4:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassino viharatha ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, dhammānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya.
sn47.4:2.6.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to truly know principles.

sn47.4:3.1.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti, tepi kāye kāyānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, kāyassa pariññāya;
sn47.4:3.1.eng: Those mendicants who are trainees—who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary from the yoke—also meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to fully understand the body.

sn47.4:3.2.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, vedanānaṃ pariññāya;
sn47.4:3.2.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to fully understand feelings.

sn47.4:3.3.pli: citte cittānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, cittassa pariññāya;
sn47.4:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to fully understand the mind.

sn47.4:3.4.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, dhammānaṃ pariññāya.
sn47.4:3.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, so as to fully understand principles.

sn47.4:4.1.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tepi kāye kāyānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, kāyena visaṃyuttā;
sn47.4:4.1.eng: Those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—also meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, detached from the body.

sn47.4:4.2.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, vedanāhi visaṃyuttā;
sn47.4:4.2.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, detached from feelings.

sn47.4:4.3.pli: citte cittānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, cittena visaṃyuttā;
sn47.4:4.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, detached from the mind.

sn47.4:4.4.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassino viharanti ātāpino sampajānā ekodibhūtā vippasannacittā samāhitā ekaggacittā, dhammehi visaṃyuttā.
sn47.4:4.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, at one, with minds that are clear, immersed in samādhi, and unified, detached from principles.

sn47.4:5.1.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, te vo, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imesaṃ catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanāya samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā”ti.
sn47.4:5.1.eng: Those mendicants who are junior—recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training—should be encouraged, supported, and established in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.40:1.1.pli: “Satipaṭṭhānañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi satipaṭṭhānabhāvanañca satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāgāminiñca paṭipadaṃ.
sn47.40:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you mindfulness meditation, the development of mindfulness meditation, and the practice that leads to the development of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.40:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.40:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.40:1.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.40:1.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.40:1.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.40:2.1.eng: And what is the development of mindfulness meditation?

sn47.40:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu samudayadhammānupassī kāyasmiṃ viharati, vayadhammānupassī kāyasmiṃ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī kāyasmiṃ viharati, ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.40:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and vanish—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.40:2.5.pli: samudayadhammānupassī dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī dhammesu viharati, ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.40:2.5.eng: principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and fall—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.40:2.6.eng: This is called the development of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.40:3.1.eng: And what is the practice that leads to the development of mindfulness meditation?

sn47.40:3.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn47.40:3.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
sn47.40:3.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn47.40:3.4.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the development of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.41:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, you should meditate with your mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.41:1.3.eng: Don’t let freedom from death escape you.

sn47.41:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.41:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.41:1.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.41:1.8.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.41:1.8.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.41:1.9.pli: Imesu, bhikkhave, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharatha.
sn47.41:1.9.eng: You should meditate with your mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.41:1.10.eng: Don’t let freedom from death escape you.”

sn47.42:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and the ending of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.42:1.3.eng: And what is the origin of the body?

sn47.42:1.5.eng: When fuel ceases, the body ends.

sn47.42:1.8.eng: The mind originates from name and form.

sn47.42:1.9.eng: When name and form cease, the mind ends.

sn47.42:1.10.eng: Principles originate from application of mind.

sn47.42:1.11.eng: When application of mind ends, principles end.”

sn47.43:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn47.43:1.3.pli: “ekamidāhaṃ, bhikkhave, samayaṃ uruvelāyaṃ viharāmi najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn47.43:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, this one time, when I was first awakened, I was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn47.43:1.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn47.43:1.4.eng: As I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:

sn47.43:1.5.pli: ‘ekāyanvāyaṃ maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.43:1.5.eng: ‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.

sn47.43:2.2.pli: Kāye vā bhikkhu kāyānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.43:2.2.eng: A mendicant would meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.43:2.3.eng: Or they’d meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.43:2.5.pli: dhammesu vā bhikkhu dhammānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.43:2.5.eng: or principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.43:2.6.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā’ti.
sn47.43:2.6.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.’

sn47.43:3.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati mama cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito mama purato pāturahosi.
sn47.43:3.1.eng: And then the divinity Sahampati, knowing my train of thought, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of me.

sn47.43:3.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yenāhaṃ tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā maṃ etadavoca:
sn47.43:3.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn47.43:3.3.eng: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn47.43:3.4.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhante, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.43:3.4.eng: Sir, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.

sn47.43:4.2.pli: Kāye vā, bhante, bhikkhu kāyānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.43:4.2.eng: A mendicant would meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.43:4.3.eng: Or they’d meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.43:4.5.pli: dhammesu vā, bhante, bhikkhu dhammānupassī vihareyya ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.43:4.5.eng: or principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.43:4.6.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhante, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā’ti.
sn47.43:4.6.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.’

sn47.43:5.1.eng: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.

sn47.43:5.2.eng: Then he went on to say:

sn47.43:6.1.eng: “The compassionate one, <j>who sees the ending of rebirth,

sn47.43:6.3.eng: By this path people crossed over before,

sn47.43:6.4.eng: will cross over, and are crossing over.’”

sn47.44:1.2.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn47.44:1.3.eng: And how is a mendicant mindful?

sn47.44:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.44:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.44:1.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.44:1.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.44:1.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.44:1.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
sn47.44:1.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.

sn47.44:1.10.eng: This is my instruction to you.”

sn47.45:1.1.pli: “‘Kusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno cattāro satipaṭṭhāne sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.45:1.1.eng: “Rightly speaking, mendicants, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the skillful’.

sn47.45:1.2.pli: Kevalo hāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kusalarāsi, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.45:1.2.eng: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the skillful.

sn47.45:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.45:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.45:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.45:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.45:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.45:2.6.pli: ‘Kusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.45:2.6.eng: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the skillful’.

sn47.45:2.7.pli: Kevalo hāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kusalarāsi, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti.
sn47.45:2.7.eng: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the skillful.”

sn47.46:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.46:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.46:2.1.pli: “Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn47.46:2.1.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn47.46:2.2.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu.
sn47.46:2.2.eng: “Well then, mendicant, you should purify the starting point of skillful qualities.

sn47.46:2.3.eng: What is the starting point of skillful qualities?

sn47.46:2.4.pli: Idha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharāhi ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhassu sikkhāpadesu.
sn47.46:2.4.eng: Live restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourself well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.

sn47.46:2.5.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharissasi ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhassu sikkhāpadesu; tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveyyāsi.
sn47.46:2.5.eng: When you’ve done this, you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, depending on and grounded on ethics.

sn47.46:3.2.pli: Idha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.46:3.2.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.46:3.3.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.46:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.46:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.46:3.6.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāvessasi, tato tuyhaṃ, bhikkhu, yā ratti vā divaso vā āgamissati vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihānī”ti.
sn47.46:3.6.eng: When you develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way, depending on and grounded on ethics, you can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.”

sn47.46:3.7.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn47.46:3.7.eng: And then that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn47.46:4.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
sn47.46:4.1.eng: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn47.46:4.2.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn47.46:4.2.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn47.46:4.3.pli: Aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn47.46:4.3.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn47.47:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn47.47:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and said:

sn47.47:1.2.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn47.47:1.2.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn47.47:1.3.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu.
sn47.47:1.3.eng: “Well then, mendicant, you should purify the starting point of skillful qualities.

sn47.47:1.4.eng: What is the beginning of skillful qualities?

sn47.47:1.5.pli: Idha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāvessasi.
sn47.47:1.5.eng: Give up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind and develop good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn47.47:1.8.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāvessasi, vacīduccaritaṃ pahāya vacīsucaritaṃ bhāvessasi, manoduccaritaṃ pahāya manosucaritaṃ bhāvessasi, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveyyāsi.
sn47.47:1.8.eng: When you’ve done this, you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, depending on and grounded on ethics.

sn47.47:2.2.pli: Idha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.47:2.2.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.47:2.3.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.47:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.47:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.47:2.6.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāvessasi, tato tuyhaṃ, bhikkhu, yā ratti vā divaso vā āgamissati vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihānī”ti …pe…
sn47.47:2.6.eng: When you develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way, depending on and grounded on ethics, you can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.” …

sn47.47:2.7.pli: aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn47.47:2.7.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn47.48:1.1.pli: “Ye, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca kho sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā, te vo, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanāya samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
sn47.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, those for whom you have sympathy, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.48:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.48:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.48:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.48:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.48:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.48:2.6.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā, te vo, bhikkhave, imesaṃ catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvanāya samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā”ti.
sn47.48:2.6.eng: Those for whom you have sympathy, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.49:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn47.49:1.5.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ pariññāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
sn47.49:1.5.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation should be developed to completely understand these three feelings.

sn47.49:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.49:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.49:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.49:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.49:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.49:2.6.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ pariññāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
sn47.49:2.6.eng: These four kinds of mindfulness meditation should be developed to completely understand these three feelings.”

sn47.5:1.3.pli: “‘akusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno pañca nīvaraṇe sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.5:1.3.eng: “Rightly speaking, mendicants, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.

sn47.5:1.4.pli: Kevalo hāyaṃ, bhikkhave, akusalarāsi, yadidaṃ—pañca nīvaraṇā.
sn47.5:1.4.eng: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.

sn47.5:1.6.eng: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

sn47.5:1.7.pli: ‘Akusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno ime pañca nīvaraṇe sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.5:1.7.eng: Rightly speaking, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.

sn47.5:1.8.pli: Kevalo hāyaṃ, bhikkhave, akusalarāsi, yadidaṃ—pañca nīvaraṇā.
sn47.5:1.8.eng: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.

sn47.5:2.1.pli: ‘Kusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno cattāro satipaṭṭhāne sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.5:2.1.eng: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the skillful’.

sn47.5:2.2.pli: Kevalo hāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kusalarāsi, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.5:2.2.eng: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the skillful.

sn47.5:2.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.5:2.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.5:2.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.5:2.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

sn47.5:2.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.5:2.7.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.5:2.8.pli: ‘Kusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.5:2.8.eng: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the skillful’.

sn47.5:2.9.pli: Kevalo hāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kusalarāsi, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti.
sn47.5:2.9.eng: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the skillful.”

sn47.50:1.3.eng: The defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

sn47.50:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇannaṃ āsavānaṃ pahānāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
sn47.50:1.5.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation should be developed to give up these three defilements.

sn47.50:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.50:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.50:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.50:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.50:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.50:2.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇannaṃ āsavānaṃ pahānāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
sn47.50:2.6.eng: These four kinds of mindfulness meditation should be developed to give up these three defilements.”
